I’m trying to better understands the conventions of the model theory library, and
Looking at the Tarski-Vaught test, docs#FirstOrder.Language.Substructure.isElementary_of_exists, I see that in the main hypothesis we have (φ : L.BoundedFormula Empty (n + 1)) (x : Fin n → S) (a : M) while what I expected was φ : L.BoundedFormula S 1 (a : M)(possibly with a coercion on S).

Up to changing appropriately the realisation in the next line, the two should be equivalent (?) and the latter feels more natural. (If I’m not mistaken there shouldn’t be much of a difference between the textbook notion of expanding the language with extra constant symbols and adding them to the set of variables, which also feels closer than having an L.formula in n+1 variables of which the first n are specialised)

I’m wondering what was the motivation behind the current spelling. Sorry to bother you @Aaron Anderson

Basically, a BoundedFormula has access to two kinds of variables - necessarily free variables indexed by an arbitrary type, and a bounded number of variables indexed by some Fin n. Because the Tarski-Vaught test is all about induction on quantifiers and the number of bound-able variables, I decided to formalize it in a way that only uses those variables.
Luigi Massacci has marked this topic as resolved.
